title: Columbia University
added: In the early 2000s, professor [[Joseph Massad]], held an elective course called Palestinian and Israeli Politics and Societies at Columbia. Students felt the views he espoused in the course were anti-Israel and some of them tried to disrupt his class and get him fired.<ref name="jps">{{cite journal | title=Academic Freedom and the Teaching of Palestine-Israel: The Columbia Case, Part II | journal=Journal of Palestine Studies | volume=34 | issue=4 | date=January 1, 2005 | issn=0377-919X | doi=10.1525/jps.2005.34.4.75 | pages=75â€“107 | url=https://online.ucpress.edu/jps/article-abstract/34/4/75/53373/Academic-Freedom-and-the-Teaching-of-Palestine | access-date=September 24, 2020}}</ref> In 2004, students got together with the pro-Israel campus group the [[David Project]] and produced a film called ''Columbia Unbecoming'', accusing Massad and two other professors of intimidating or treating unfairly students with pro-Israel views. The film led to a committee being appointed by Bollinger which exonerated the professors in the spring of 2005.<ref name="report">{{cite web

}}</ref> However, the committee's report criticized Columbia's inadequate grievance procedures.<ref name="bdh05apr7">{{cite web | last=Doob | first=Gabriella | title=Columbia report addresses anti-Semitism charges | website=Brown Daily Herald | date=April 7, 2005 | url=https://www.browndailyherald.com/2005/04/07/columbia-report-addresses-antisemitism-charges/ | access-date=September 25, 2020}}</ref>
